Award.AwardTitle: AF: EAGER: Phase Transitions in Markov Chain Mixing Times

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms. MCMC algorithms are widely used in a variety of scientific fields, for instance, for Bayesian inference and for simulations of idealized models of physical systems. At the heart of an MCMC algorithm is a Markov chain whose equilibrium distribution is of particular interest. The efficiency of this Markov chain is measured by its mixing time, which is the requisite number of steps to reach this equilibrium distribution of interest. In this project the PI will design new tools for analyzing the mixing time of Markov chains to gain a better understanding of settings where MCMC algorithms are efficient.

The work in this project will enhance scientific studies that rely on MCMC algorithms, and will strengthen ties between the study of randomized algorithms in theoretical computer science with the study of phase transitions in statistical physics. The PI will organize a workshop on topics related to this project, bringing together researchers from statistical physics, discrete mathematics and theoretical computer science.

The project aims to connect the mixing time of well-studied Markov chains with phase transitions in the underlying system. In this project the PI will analyze Markov chains that are popular for statistical physics and combinatorial models. The goal is to understand the mixing time of these Markov chains and determine how the mixing time relates to phase transitions in the associated models. Of particular interest is analyzing the mixing time at the critical points of phase transitions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies the convergence rate of Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms.  MCMC methods are a widely-used tool in many scientific fields  for associated inference problems.  The algorithms are used for randomly sampling from probability distributions defined on a large set, and their efficiency depends on fast convergence to the limiting distribution.  The focus of this project is to understand when MCMC algorithms quickly converge to their limiting distribution and hence these methods provide accurate estimates.  

This project presents new tools for proving fast convergence of Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods.  The main results focus on the statistical physics model of a gas known as the hard-core gas model.  We establish new connections between the convergence rate of simple Markov chains for the hard-core model and the behavior of widely-used inference tool known as Belief Propagation (BP).  As a consequence we also get new results showing fast convergence of BP-type algorithms.  In addition, this project establishes new connections between the converge rate of MCMC algorithms with statistical physics phase transitions.  These connections provide new inter-disciplinary connections and yield new insights about the behavior of MCMC algorithms.  The PI helped organize interdisciplinary workshops and the project funded a PhD student and postdoc.
